skill.name: creating-skills
skill.description: Use when creating new Claude Code skills or improving existing ones - ensures skills are discoverable, scannable, and effective through proper structure, CSO optimization, and real examples

skill.author: AgentWorkforce

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing only markdown text and code examples. No executable code, no file system access, no network operations, no environment variable access. Educational content only.

content.value_statement: Claude Code skills help AI agents apply proven techniques across projects. This guide covers proper structure, search optimization, and real examples to make skills discoverable and actionable for future use.
actual_capabilities: Define proper skill frontmatter with name and description
Optimize skill descriptions for Claude Search (CSO)
Structure skill content with overview, when to use, and examples
Write effective code examples with good and bad approaches
Organize multi-file skills with supporting files and examples
Apply degrees of freedom matching task complexity
limitations: Does not execute or validate skill files automatically
Does not create skill directory structure
Does not generate skill metadata or validate frontmatter
Does not integrate with version control systems

use_cases.title: Build new skills from scratch
use_cases.description: Create well-structured skills following proven patterns for maximum discoverability and effectiveness.

use_cases.title: Improve existing skills
use_cases.description: Refactor and optimize current skills for better searchability and token efficiency.

use_cases.title: Establish skill standards
use_cases.description: Define organizational conventions for team-wide skill development and documentation.

prompt_templates.title: New skill setup
prompt_templates.prompt: Use creating-skills to help me create a new skill for [technique]. What structure should I use? What should the frontmatter contain?

prompt_templates.title: Description optimization
prompt_templates.prompt: Use creating-skills to review my skill description. Is it optimized for Claude Search? Does it include proper triggers?

prompt_templates.title: Example guidance
prompt_templates.prompt: Use creating-skills to help me write a code example for my skill. Show me both good and bad approaches.

prompt_templates.title: Skill validation
prompt_templates.prompt: Use creating-skills to audit my skill. Does it follow the checklist? What improvements are needed?

best_practices: Write skill descriptions that include both triggers (when to use) and outcomes (what it provides)
Keep skills under 500 lines and optimize for token efficiency in frequent conversations
Include one excellent example that shows both problematic and correct approaches
anti_patterns: Using vague names like 'Helper' or 'Utils' instead of action-oriented gerund forms
Writing first-person descriptions ('I help you...') instead of third-person ('Use when...')
Including time-sensitive information that becomes outdated quickly

faq.question: What tools support Claude Code skills?
faq.answer: Claude Code skills work with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code. Each tool searches skills when you describe tasks matching their descriptions.

faq.question: What is the maximum size for a skill?
faq.answer: Keep SKILL.md under 500 lines. Frequently-loaded skills should be under 200 words for token efficiency.

faq.question: How do I reference other skills?
faq.answer: Use skill names with REQUIRED or RECOMMENDED labels. Avoid force-loading file paths which wastes context tokens.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using skills?
faq.answer: Yes. Skills are read-only documentation. They cannot access files, network, or execute code on your system.

faq.question: Why is my skill not being found?
faq.answer: Check your description includes relevant triggers and keywords. Use words Claude would search for like error messages or symptoms.

faq.question: How is this different from CLAUDE.md?
faq.answer: CLAUDE.md contains project-specific conventions. Skills are reusable patterns that apply across many projects and teams.
